loans.name: Fredrick

texts.en:
Fredrick A. is 26 years old and married to Shirley.  They have one child who is six months old. They live in Katito.

Fredrick has a retail shop that he has been running for the past four years.  He is applying for his second loan from KADET LTD after successfully completing the first loan well and on time.  He intends to use the money to buy shop products like sugar, soap, bread, etc.  This business earns him a  monthly income of Kshs.10,000.

His desire is to expand his business and improve the family’s living standard.

loans.use: To buy supplies such as soap, bread and sugar to stock his retail shop.

loans.name: Muhammed

texts.en: Muhammad is a forty-six-year-old  married man with five children.  He lives in a semi-permanent house in the district of Kyenjojo, Uganda. He sells clothes, and his ambition is to start a shop and leave the mobile business. He dreams of educating his children such that they can have a bright future.  Muhammed needs the credit to buy clothes to resell during the Christmas season.

loans.use: To buy clothes to resell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow and chaff cutter.

loans.name: Turumkan's Group

texts.en:
Turumkan T., 44, is the treasurer of the group. She is the resident of Tup, a small town located in the North of Kyrgyzstan in Isykul region. Turumkan is married to a farmer. She has two sons and two daughters. The first son and the first daughter work in Bishkek and the other children study at school. 

In order to earn money to cover family expenses, Turumkan and her husband breed cattle, then resell them at higher prices after fattening. In this way they earn 3000 soms per month. With money received from the loan, the family wants to purchase two cattle for breeding. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase cattle for breeding

loans.name: Nyiringabo

texts.fr: S. NYIRINGABO est commerçant.  Il est marié, et son niveau d’éducation est primaire.  Il va utiliser son prêt pour acheter des robes de mariages sacs et tricots (bodies pour femmes).  Son stratégie pour la croissance de l’affaire est d’épargner, est l’augmentation  de l’affaire.  Il voudrait l’augmentation ou la capacité d’accueillir beaucoup de clients.  Il voudrait aussi construire une nouvelle maison.
texts.en: Nyiringabo S. is a business man. He is married and has primary education. He will use his loan to buy wedding accessories, bags and ladies' bodysuits. His strategy to develop the business is to save and to increase the activity. He would like to grow and to be able to accommodate many customers. He also would like to build a new house.

loans.use: Purchase of wedding accessories, bags and bodysuits.

loans.name: William

texts.en: William is a 50-year-old married man with six children living in Kyenjojo, Uganda. He has been a farmer for the last six years.  He started with small scale farmingand now farms on a large scale.  William wants a loan to cultivate more land for farming (planting irish potatoes, bananas, and sugarcane).

loans.use: To plant more crops

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en:
Gladys C. is a 56-year-old mother from Centro Poblacion, Culasi, Antique, Philippines. She is married to Raul C., a barangay secretary. Through their industry and courage, and with the support of ASHI, some of their children have already finished college.

She is presently engaged in a piggery project. This project has helped her especially with the educational expense for her children. The effort and money that she and her husband had invested into the education of their children is worth it because they are very diligent in their studies. One of her children graduated from college with flying colors.

Gladys never tired in supporting her husband in providing for the needs of the family because she believes that someday they will reach their dreams. 

She is a pioneered member of ASHI Antique North Branch.  In addition to that, for almost 11 years of membership she has maintained good performance.  That is why she has been nominated as an outstanding member of that branch.

Presently, she has successfully paid her last loan and is now requesting a new loan of Php. 30,0000. This amount will be used to purchase piglets and feeds. She wants to have many pigs because she wants to earn more income for the future of her children who are still studying.

Her greatest dream in life is that all of her children will finished their college studies so that they will get a decent job someday. She also want to own a concrete house free from floods.

loans.use: To buy piglets and feeds

loans.name: Saimon

texts.en:
Saimon is a married man with one child who is still young for school. He lives in a rental house that has neither electricity nor piped water. His greatest monthly expenses are food and rent.

He has been operating a video café business for the past three years.  Neighbors and passersby are his potential customers. Saimon faces a major challenge of seasonality in his business. He hopes to open a well-furnished video café in the future.

With the Kshs 15,000, he wants to purchase timber and pay for labor charges to establish a video café. He decided to join Yehu to get loans and improve his business.

loans.use: To purchase timber and pay for labor charges to build video café

texts.en:
Hosea Kamau N. is 26 years old and married to Anne Wangechi, who helps him operate his business. They have two school-going children, ages four and one. Their residential place is in Lodwar, Kenya. He sells clothes and has been in this business for three years and earns a monthly profit of  15,000 KES.


Hosea learned about KADET LTD through a credit officer and is applying for his first loan of 50,000 KES from KADET LTD, which he intends to use to buy more clothes. The anticipated profits he plans to use to expand the boutique business.


In the future, Hosea wishes to have a large boutique in Lodwar town. His deeper desire is to support his family.

loans.name: Ma. Jeren

Jeren owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for sale. Ma. Jeren is just starting this business.

In 2010, Ma. Jeren joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ma. Jeren has successfully repaid a previous loan  from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. Ma. Jeren is requesting a new loan of 20000 PHP, which will be used to purchase breeding livestock. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Ma. Jeren from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.name: Loh

texts.en:
Loh M. is a 46-year-old married woman blessed with six children. She shares three rooms with her six children in Susia, a quarter in Bamenda, in the Northwest region of Cameroon.

Mariana has faced many difficulties in her life, ranging from the inability to meet her daily needs, to the increasing demands of her children. Among other challenges, she has also had difficulties with inadequate capital to expand her business. 

With this loan, she plans to buy more clothes, thread, foodstuff like beans, rice, tomato, onion, garlic, maggi, sugar, and cassava flakes commonly known as garri.  She thinks her business will succeed because her business site is close to the road and she is friendly, thus has many clients. She has minimized risk by diversifying her business. Her activity will help her community in reducing the cost of transportation to buy foodstuff, and their cordial relationship will allow for negotiation to pay later.

She will use a fraction of her profit to assist her husband to provide for the children’s school needs, to meet her personal needs, and to feed her family. She prefers a loan from GHAPE because of the training she frequently receives, the follow-up and moral support given her by the GHAPE office, and the low cost in obtaining and paying back a loan.

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instils a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: To buy clothes and foodstuff to sell

loans.name: Sinai Group

texts.fr: Nabazairois B. est entrepreneur, âgée de 30 ans, mariée, mère de 7 enfants.  Elle vend des divers (commerce général). Elle fait également la vente de poulets de chair. Elle  commença son business  avec son fonds propre. Il ya 10 qu’elle est en action. Plus tard, elle bénéficia de crédit de l’IMF  Hekima de 50$ en 2008. Elle installe ses produits  au marché central de Virunga et parfois au long de la rue ambiante. Ce nouveau crédit doit lui servir de s’approvisionner  avec  80 individus des poulets de chair pour le revendre aux restaurants, bars, hôtels de la ville. En plus, elle ambitionne avoir une grande salle d’exposition de ses produits. La cliente Nabazairois B. remercie Hekima pour  ses actions en faveur de pauvres exclus de banque classique. Le groupe Sinaï est constitué de16 membres.
texts.en: Barbara Nabazairois is a business woman, aged 30, married and mother of seven children. She sells various products (general store). She also sells broilers. She began her business with her savings about ten years ago. Later, she received a loan of $ 50 from the MFI Hekima, in 2008. She sells her products at the central market of Virunga and sometimes along the street. This new loan will allow her to purchase about 80 broilers to be sold to restaurants, bars and hotels in the city. In addition, she aims to have a large showroom for her products. Barbara Nabazairois is grateful to Hekima for supporting poor people who are excluded from traditional banking. The Sinai group consists of 16 members.

loans.use: Purchase of 80 boilers

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Erdenesuvd

texts.en:

For a living, she owns and operates a jewelry business.  At the same time, she has been studying at the University of Science and Technology since 2009.  With the earnings, she has been paying her tuition fee.  She recently passed a driving test and obtained her driving license. She is requesting a loan for 1,200,000 MNT to increase her business.

loans.use: To increase business

texts.en: Islam D. is a 43 year-old man who is married and lives in the city of Saatli in Southern Azerbaijan. Islam is the head of a big family. He has two daughters and one son. He sells meat and dairy produced in his cattle-breeding business at the Saatli bazaar. Before Islam started his business in 2005, his family lacked the means to cover all of their expenses.  Since then the business has been the only source of income for Islam's family. His brother helps him in his business. This is Islam’s first loan from Aqroinvest and Kiva. Islam used the 1000 AZN loan to buy two cows. Now Islam has three cows. After repaying this loan Islam plans to take out another loan to buy five more cows.

loans.name: Yezeh

texts.en:
Yezeh J. is a 48-year-old married woman blessed with two children. She shares three rooms with her two children in Ndamukong, a quarter in Bamenda, in the northwest region of Cameroon.

J. has faced many difficulties in her life, ranging from the inability to meet her daily needs to the increasing demands of her children. Among other challenges, she has also had difficulties with inadequate capital to expand her business. With this loan, she plans to invest in her poultry farm and to buy firewood. She thinks her business will succeed because her business site is accessible and she is friendly, thus successful in her business. She has minimized risk by diversifying her business. Her activity will help her community in reducing the cost of transportation to buy fowls, and their cordial relationship will allow for negotiations to pay later.

J. will use a fraction of her profit to assist her husband provide for the children’s school needs, to meet her personal needs, and to feed her family. She prefers a loan from GHAPE because of the training she frequently receives, the follow-up and moral support given her by the GHAPE office, and the low cost in obtaining and paying back a loan.

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instils a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: To purchase day-old chicks and feed

loans.name: Rukiri Tukore Group B-Ibanda

texts.en:
O. Gilva, 35 years old, pleads a cause with Rukiri Tukore group B. For 7 years now, he has been in business selling agricultural products in Rukiri-Ibanda.

Principally, he has been selling maize and coffee. The fact that he does agriculture has worked in his favor. Needless to say this has made it easier for his business as he has been selling mostly what he harvests. He says his business began when he sold off his goats. The money he got enabled him to improve his farming gardens; hence, improving his harvests. Gilva is happily married with 6 kids. He says he is going to buy more bags of coffee for resale with this loan.

loans.use: To purchase more coffee for resale

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en: Ruth is a 28-year-old married woman with one child.  They live in Kyenjojo, Uganda, in a permanent rented house.  She has a desire to own a house in the next six years.  She runs a retail shop and her business dream is to become a wholesale trader.   Ruth wants a loan to buy more soft drinks, salt, sugar, and other general merchandise.

loans.use: To buy soft drinks, salt, sugar, and other general merchandise

loans.name: Robert

texts.en: Robert is a thirty-two-year-old married man with four children.  He lives in a permanent house in the district of Kyenjojo, Uganda. He sells motorcycle spare parts.  In the future, he wants to expand his business and educate his children. He wants a loan to buy more spare parts to resell.

loans.use: To buy spare parts to resell

loans.name: Surkhay

texts.en: Surkhay A. is a 45 year-old-man who lives in the city of Imishli with his family.  He is married and a father of two sons. Surkhay owns a small grocery store in the city of Imishli. His wife helps him in the business which is their only source of income.  This is the first loan Surkhay has received from Aqroinvest and Kiva.  He used it to buy products to sell in his store to increase sales.  After repaying this loan of 1000 AZN he plans to take out another loan to expand this business and open a new store.

loans.use: to buy products to sell in the store

loans.name: Elvie

texts.en:
Elvie B. is from the village of Malintuboan, Labason, Zamboanga del Norte. She is 41 years old. Elvie is married and has school-aged children. To make a living, Elvie owns & operates a business venture in the food sector operating a fishing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from harvesting & selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. Elvie has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2010, Elvie joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elvie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional fish to sell. Elvie is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fish to sell. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Elvie from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional fish to sell

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther is a married woman with two daughters, all of whom graduated from school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family. 

For over ten years, she has operated a Leso’s (Kiko’s) selling business. She sells wholesale and retail from home to her neighbors, especially women. Esther faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business.  She hopes to establish a cloth selling shop in the future.

With the Kshs 15,000,  she wants to purchase 10 pairs of Leso’s (Kiko’s) for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to improve her business.

loans.use: To purchase clothes for resale

loans.name: John

texts.en: Twenty-six-year-old John would like a loan to buy clothes to resell. He lives in Kyenjojo, Uganda, in a semi-permanent house.  His dream is to educate his children.  He sells first-hand clothes and has a business aspiration of becoming a wholesaler in the future.

loans.use: To buy clothes to resell

loans.name: Zaina

texts.en:
Zaina N. lives in the Kisaasi neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has 4 children, all of whom are in school.  She also takes care of additional family members (brother). 

Zaina has a business selling second-hand clothes.  She has been in this business for over 10 years, and she works 7 days out of every week. Zaina sells her products at the market by means of retail. 

Zaina has requested a loan of 800000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bales of second-hand clothes.   She also generates additional income through a retail shop.The main business challenges for Zaina include thieves and transportation.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to start importing second-hand clothes and to sell wholesale only. 

Zaina lives in a home that she rents.  She has access to electricity and piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include rent, food, school fees, and medication.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to resell

loans.name: Hasifa

texts.en:
Hasifa N. lives in the Mengo MacKay neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has 5 children, all of whom are in school.  She also takes care of additional family members (house girl).    Hasifa has a business of a restaurant.  She has been in this business for 3 years, and she works 6 days out of every week. 

Hasifa has requested a loan of 600000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bunches of bananas, cooking oil, rice, beef, chicken, sweet and Irish potatoes.  

The main business challenges for Hasifa include thieves and transportation.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own a fully stocked restaurant and to start an outside catering department.   

Hasifa lives in a home that she rents.  She has access to electricity but doesn't have access to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include rent, food, school fees, and medication.

loans.use: To buy more food for restaurant

loans.name: Piyinento

texts.en: Piyinento is a sixty-six-year-old married man with three children.  He lives in a permanent house in the district of Kyenjojo, Uganda, and has a dream of educating his children.  He wants to be a large wholesale supplier of beer and soft drink. Piyinento wants a loan to purchase beer and soft drinks.

loans.use: To purchase beer and soft drinks to sell

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en: Stephen is a thirty-four-year-old married man with three children, living in a semi-permanent house in the district of Kyenjojo, Uganda.  He has a desire to build a permanent house for his family.  As a farmer he saved money and started a boutique.  He dreams of starting up a big boutique in town.  Stephen wants a loan to buy clothes to resell.

loans.use: To buy clothes to resell

loans.name: Bisiti

texts.en:
Bisiti is a married woman with two children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

She has been operating a fresh water selling business for the past three years.  Neighbors are her potential customers. Bisiti faces a major challenge in the high cost of transportation in her business. She hopes to own a big water tank in the future. 

With the Kshs 15,000, she wants to purchase a water tank. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase a water tank

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret Y. is 45-year-old woman and a mother of four. Her children are aged 22 (twins), 16, and 12 years old. She has been in the grocery business for the past ten years in Eldoret, Kenya. She was introduced to KADET by a member of the group and this is her sixth loan with KADET. 

Margaret is applying for 80,000 Kenyan shillings, which she plans to use to buy onions, potatoes, mangoes, and to boost her stock. This will enable her to live a good and comfortable life. She plans to add more stock to her grocery business and to see her children obtain better education.

loans.use: To buy onions, potatoes, and mangoes

loans.name: Basirat

texts.fr: Basirat a 40 ans et est mariée. Elle a 2 enfants en charge.  Elle est revendeuse de charbons de bois pour pouvoir aider son mari au foyer. Cette activité rapporte tellement qu’elle a déjà remboursé plusieurs  crédits  et cumule 3 ans d’expérience. Elle s’approvisionne au Nord du pays à Anié  et revend ensuite au marché local d’Agoè Zongo.   L’objet de ce prêt sera essentiellement destiné à l’achat de 20 nouveaux sacs de charbons de bois.
texts.en: Basirat is 40 years old and married. She has two children in her care. She sells charcoal in order to help her husband with the household expenses. This business brings in enough profit to have allowed her to repay several loans. She already has three years of experience. She stocks up in the north of the country, in Anié, and then resells at the local market of Agoè Zongo. The purpose of this loan is basically to purchase 20 more bags of charcoal.

loans.use: Purchasing charcoal

loans.name: Violet

texts.en:
Violet is a single woman with two children, one still attends school while the eldest has graduated from school. She owns a house that has neither  electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are school fees and food for the family. 

She has been operating a firewood selling business for the past three months, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. In addition, she sells charcoal and owns rental houses to contribute to her income. Violet faces a major challenge in seasonality.  During the rainy winter season the supply of firewood is low, hence does not meet the demand of customers. She hopes to build more rental houses in the future.

She decided to join Yehu to access funds to improve her business. With the Kshs 20,000, she wants to purchase bundles of firewood and pay for electrical wiring in her home.

loans.use: To purchase firewood, and pay for electrical wiring in home

loans.name: Zumrathan's Group

texts.en:
Zumrathan A., 43, is the leader of this group.   She is a widow and is raising two daughters and a son.  Both the children are in school. 

In order to earn money to cover family expenditures, Zumrathan sells convenience goods and earns 5000 soms per month. This profit made it possible for her to make house repairs.  She hopes to obtain the loan because she needs money to purchase more goods to sell in order to increase the turnover of her business.  In the future Zumrathan wants to expand her business, and provide her children a good education.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase goods to sell

loans.name: Restuta

texts.en:
Restuta N. lives in the Kisaasi neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is single and has 5 children, 3 of whom are in school.  She also takes care of additional family members (grandchildren ).    

Restuta has a business selling charcoal.  She has been in this business for over 10 years, and she works 7 days out of every week. Restuta sells her products from home by means of retail.    

Restuta has requested a loan of 500000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags of charcoal.  She also generates additional income through room rentals.   The main business challenges for Restuta include thieves and seasonality.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to start selling wholesale only and to build more rental rooms.   

Restuta lives in a home that she owns.  She doesn't have access to electricity or piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include food, school fees, and  medication.

loans.use: To buy charcoal to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Salama

texts.en:
Salama is a married woman with two children, one of whom attends school while the other one is too young for school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

She has been operating a dry fish selling business for the past two years, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. Salama faces a major challenge in the high cost of transportation in her business. She hopes to expand and establish a retail shop in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000, she wants to purchase a bundle of fish to resell.  She decided to join Yehu because of the availability of sustainable financial services.

loans.use: To purchase fish for resale

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence N. lives in the Mengo Mackay neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has 4 children, 3 of whom are in school.  Florence has a business of a retail shop.  She has been in this business for 6 years, and she works 7 days out of every week.  Florence sells her products from home by means of retail.  

Florence has requested a loan of 500000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags of sugar, cartons of salt, boxes of soap, and cooking oil.  The main business challenges for Florence  include thieves and competition.  Her goals and aspirations are to start selling wholesale only and to educate her children up to university. 

Florence lives in a home that she rents.  She has access to electricity but doesn't have access to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include rent, food, school fees, and medication.

loans.use: To buy sugar, salt, soap, cooking oil

loans.name: Hanifahon's Group

texts.en:
Hanifahon A. has a large family.  She is 44 years old.  Together with her husband, they are raising six children. The older children help the parents run their family business, the younger children are school pupils.  

The most widespread business in Kyrgyz villages is farming and cattle breeding.  For 20 years, the family has been getting profits from cultivating agricultural production and reselling cattle. Currently Hanifahon keeps a cow with a calf to be fattened and resold.  Their earnings have made possible to give their children a proper education, and also to make house repairs. 

In order to increase the total number of animals, the family wants to purchase 3 sheep. For this purpose they need to get a loan.  In the future, they aim to arrange their children’s weddings.

	--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase 3 sheep

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah N. lives in the Kawempe neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has 6 children, all of whom are in school.  

Sarah has a tailoring business.  She has been in this business for over 10 years, and she works 6 days out of every week. Sarah sells her products from home by means of retail.   

Sarah has requested a loan of 500000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more rolls of cloth materials.  She also generates additional income through room rentals.  

The main business challenges for Sarah include thieves and seasonality.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own a tailoring school and to build more rental rooms.   

Sarah lives in a home that she owns.  She has access to electricity and piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include food, school fees, and medication.

loans.use: To buy more rolls of cloth

loans.name: Jjungwe Bukooka Alinyikira Development Group - Mityana

texts.en: 37-year-old S. Salongo's has been affiliated with the Jjungwe Bukooka Alinyikira development group in Mityana for the past decade. His means of subsistence over the course of this decade have been a liquor and beer sales business in Bujungwe. It is a business he began with capital from his earlier charcoal sales business. Diligence and determination are words that describe Salongo. His clientele cut across from wholesalers to hawkers. Salongo is happily married with 8 kids. To supplement his profit from beer sales, he also sells coffee. With this loan, he says he is going to purchase more liquor and crates of beer for resale.

loans.use: The purchase of more liquor and crates of beer for resell

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine N. lives in the Mengo Mackay  neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has 3 children, one of whom is in school.  Christine has a restaurant business.  She has been in this business for less than one year, and she works 7 days out of every week. Christine sells her products from home by means of retail.     

Christine  has requested a loan of 500000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bunches of bananas, beef, sweet and Irish potatoes, and rice.  

The main business challenges for Christine include seasonality and transportation.  Her goals and aspirations are to start selling wholesale only and to educate her children up to university.   

Florence lives in a home that she rents.  She has access to electricity but doesn't have access to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include rent, food, school fees, and medication.

loans.use: To buy bananas, beef, sweet and Irish potatoes, and rice

loans.name: Hamisi

texts.en:
A. is a married man with two children, one of whom attends school while the other is still too young for school. He lives in a rental house that neither has electricity nor piped water. His greatest monthly expenses are school fees and rent bills.

He has been operating a cobbling business for the past six years.   Passersby and neighbors are his potential customers.  A. faces a major challenge of seasonality because of the unavailability of supplies, especially wax,  for the cobbling business. He hopes to establish a wholesale shop to sell shoes in the future.

With the Kshs 15,000, he wants to purchase a bundle of shoe soles and shoes to sell. He decided to join Yehu because of efficiency of financial services.

loans.use: To purchase shoe soles and shoes

loans.name: Zyinat's Group

texts.en:
Zyinat M. is 49.  She is married and has four adult children. All of them have their own job, except the youngest one who is still a schoolboy.

The family budget is contributed to by the parents and elder children:  the head of the family is a secretary, the son earns income by working in a military department, the daughters are engaged in farming, and Zyinat herself has a job as head of the teaching department. Out of the total earnings,  the family has managed to prepare for their daughter’s dowry. 

The main aim of getting this loan is to start a livestock breeding business. Zyinat and her family are planning to purchase sheep for fattening and resale.  In the future, their intention is to purchase lot in order to build a new house for their eldest son.

	--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To buy sheep

loans.name: Erdenechimeg

texts.en:
Erdenechimeg B. is 43 years old and lives with her husband and two children in Han-Uul province in UlaanB., the capital city of Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent in a rented fence. Her youngest daughter attends a local secondary school. 

Erdenechimeg and her husband manage a clothing trade business. She sells a variety of clothing items out of a stall in the trade center of their province. She started her clothing business in September 2010 with capital of 900,000 MNT. Since then, they have managed to stabilize their business operation and today, their working capital exceeds 1,300,000 MNT. Since operating this business, they have earned a monthly income of 450,000 MNT and have used their earnings to provide for their family.

For the future, Erdenechimeg hopes to continue to grow her business and expand by selling a wide variety of clothes to her customers. She is a helpful and hardworking person and says, "We work very hard to create a nice and decent future for our children." She is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan to purchase more winter clothes in order to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase winter clothes for resale

loans.name: Dilrabohon's Group

texts.en:
Dilrabohon M. is 40 aged woman.  She is married and is bringing up three children together with her husband. The youngest children are school pupils.

The adult members of this family earn their livelihood in different ways: the head of the family is a private driver, Dilrabohon is a school teacher, and the eldest daughter adds to the family budget by working as a dressmaker.

The family wants to purchase construction materials in order to build a new house.  This is the main goal of obtaining a loan. In the future, Dilrabohon is planning to prepare a dowry for her daughter. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase building materials to build new house

loans.name: Mostafa

texts.en:
Mostafa is from Iraq. He is 32 years old. He is married and has 2 children. 

In 2008, Mostafa decided to open his own store where he sells a wide variety of frozen meat. He has more experience now and he is well-known in his local area. 

He is requesting a $2400 loan to renovate his store and coat the walls with ceramic. His goal is to increase his sales and expand his store in the future.

loans.use: Renovate his store and coat the walls with ceramic

loans.name: Zainab's Group

texts.en:
Zainab O. is a middle-aged woman who is a widow. Her 2 children live separately: her son is working in Russia, her daughter is married and has her own family.

Zainab increases her regular income by breeding cattle.  Currently, she has a cow with a heifer.  Several years ago her son helped her to start this business by putting up some amount of money.

In order to increase her cattle stock and enlarge the family budget, Zainab wants to purchase more cattle for keeping and fattening. For this purpose she needs to get a loan. Her future plans include building a bath-house.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To buy more cattle

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en:
Mercy has been practicing farming for the last five years in Ndunyu Njeru town. She is a 30-year-old single lady with five children.

She was introduced to KADET by a credit officer from KADET. This will be her first loan. She plans to use the loan amount to buy fertilizers, seedlings and cater for the labour.

In the future, Mercy hopes to increase farm production by practicing large-scale farming

loans.use: To buy fertilizers, seedlings and provide food for the hired laborers.

loans.name: Erduujargal

texts.en:
Erduujargal M. is 36 years old and lives with sister and mother in the Songinohairhan district of Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia's capital city. She and her family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian tent home, in a housing district in the city. Her sister, age 10, attends a secondary school. 

Erduujargal operates a clothes selling business in a rented stand at the trade center of her district. She rents her stall at a monthly rental fee of 200,000 MNT. She started his business in 2005 and has since gained much experience as a businesswoman. She sells a variety of clothing items that are imported from China twice a month. After years of successful operation, her monthly business revenue has reached 1,000,000 MNT. She is a very clever and business-minded person. She hopes to continue to grow her business in the future, and plans to buy a car for herself. 

Erduujargal  is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to purchase more evening dresses to sell at her stall for the upcoming New Year holiday.

loans.use: To purchase evening dresses to sell for upcoming New Year holiday

loans.name: Ainagul's Group

texts.en:
Ainagul A. is a mother of three daughters. She has brought them up together with her husband. By now, the parents have given away their elder daughters, who now live separately.  But the youngest one, being a light-hearted teenager, still needs care and proper upbringing. 

Ten years ago, the family had no opportunity to find a stable job, therefore they began their private trading business. Currently, Ainagul  sells apples in the local market with the help of her spouse.  Their earnings have made it possible for them to obtain a car and to arrange their daughters’ marriages. 

The family aims to improve their well-being, therefore they want to increase their total income. The most optimal way to realize these plans is to increase product turnover.  The family hopes to obtain a loan for this purpose.  In the future, Ainagul wants to purchase a home. 

	--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase apples for sale

loans.name: Haidar

texts.en:
Haidar is from Iraq. He is 24 years old, married, and has 2 children. 

In 2006, after working for 2 years in another grocery shop, Haidar decided to open his own grocery shop. Now he has a a lot of experience in this field. He is well-known in his local community and has a good reputation.

He is requesting a $2400 loan to renovate his shop and add an outside stand. He aims to expand his business and improve his family's life style.

loans.use: Renovate his shop and add an outside stand

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en:
Gladys K. lives in the Naguru neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is single and has four children, all of whom are in school.  Gladys has a business of a restaurant. She has been in this business for 10 years and she works seven days out of every week. Gladys sells her products in a shop on a retail basis.  

Gladys has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bunches of bananas, beef, sweet and Irish potatoes and rice. The main business challenges for Gladys include seasonality and transportation.

Her goals and aspirations for her business are to start selling on a wholesale basis only and also to educate her children up to university. Gladys lives in a home that she rents; she has access to electricity but doesn't have access to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include rent, food, school fees and medication.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuff like bunches of bananas, beef, sweet and Irish potatoes and rice.

loans.name: Mwanamkasi

texts.en:
Mwanamkasi is a married woman with three children. Two of her children attend school and one is too young for school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity, but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For more than five years, she has operated a vegetable business, where she sells green vegetable, tomatoes and potatoes. She sells from her home to her neighbors and passers-by.  In addition, she sells kikois (sarong-like wrapped clothing) which contributes to her income. Mwanamkasi faces the major challenge of high cost of transportation in her business. She hopes to sell wholesale in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 loan, she wants to purchase sacks of green vegetables, bananas, tomatoes, onions, potatoes and coconuts to sell. She decided to join Yehu to access funds to improve her business.

loans.use: To purchase green vegetables, bananas, tomatoes, onions, potatoes and coconuts to sell.

loans.name: Mouthana

texts.en:
S. is from Iraq. He is 28 years old. He is single and lives with 2 family members.

S. opened his own mini-market because he has a lot of experience in sales. He offers a wide variety of products. He is well-known in his community and has a good reputation.

He is requesting a $2300 loan to renovate his shop so he can increase his inventory. His plan is to expand his business and improve his living standards.

loans.use: To renovate his shop

loans.name: Kabembe Women's Group B-Mukono

texts.en: 36 Year old Jackline K. belongs to Kabembe Women's group-Mukono. It is now 10 years since she began selling movies on tape and DVD, firewood, charcoal in Kabembe-Mukono. She credits her mother for being able to start this business. Prior to that, she was selling goats and cows. She also has a side salon business that she says helps supplement her profits. She and her husband have 4 kids who occasionally help her with running the business. Monthly, her business profits are 100,000 shillings and with this loan, she says she is going to buy more movie tapes, DVD's, firewood, and cosmetics to resell.

loans.use: The purchase of more movies on tape and DVD, firewood and cosmetics

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Benkadi  est un regroupement de neuf femmes toutes mariées dans des familles conjugales traditionnelles élargies avec leurs frères, sœurs, co-épouses, enfants et époux. Elles ont   une moyenne d’âge de 32 ans et de 4 enfants et résident à Heremakono-Nord, préfecture de BOUGOUNI, (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).  Elles se sont connues par des relations de commerce, de parenté et excellent le commerce  d’articles divers  
Dans le souci de satisfaire leurs clientèles de plus en plus nombreuses, elles ont décidé d’adhérer au programme crédit de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. Elles sont à leur quatrième prêt de groupe, les prêts trois précédents  ont été correctement remboursés. 
Avec ce prêt DIATOU S., compte acheter des sacs de charbon de bois auprès des paysans des villages environnants de BOUGOUNI. Elle effectue sa vente, en détail, au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Avec ce prêt elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 40.000 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisé dans l’activité et l’autre partie dans les frais d’éducation de leurs enfants.
texts.en:
Benkadi is a group of nine women, all married and living in traditional extended polygamous families, with their brothers, sisters, co-spouses, children and husbands. They are on the average 32 years old, with four children. They live in Heremakono-Nord, Bougoni Preferecture (the third administrative region of Mali). They know each other through business and family links and work selling various items.

In order to better meet the increasing customer demand, they have decided to join the loan program of the microfinance institution Soro Yirwaso. They are on their fourth group loan, having duly repaid three prior loans. With this loan, Diatou S. plans to purchase bags of charcoal from farmers in the villages surrounding Bougoni.  She sells retail, for cash and on credit to a customer base composed of both men and women. With this loan, she plans to achieve a monthly income of 40,000 West African Francs, a part of which will be used for the business and the other for [her] children’s education costs.

loans.use: Purchasing charcoal

loans.name: Bonface

texts.en:
Bonface is a single man. He lives in a rental house that has electricity, but not piped water. His greatest monthly expense is food for his family.

He has operated his barber shop for the past two years. Neighbors and passers-by are his potential customers. Bonface faces a major challenge of seasonality in his business. During holiday season, he gets a lot of customers, but during the month of January to May, he gets fewer customers. He hopes to expand his business in the future.

With the Kshs 15,000 loan, he wants to purchase a hair-cutting machine and hair oil. He decided to join Yehu to access loans to improve his business.

loans.use: To purchase a hair cutting-machine and hair oil.

loans.name: Zina's Group

texts.en: Zina S., 54, is a widow. She has three children: Two elder sons are married and live separately and the daughter makes her living at the capital. Two years ago, out of the proceeds from selling strawberries, the woman purchased a cow. Now she is keeping a cow and her calf; concurrently, she is an employee of a spinning factory. Zina has the duties of a sorter. In order to increase cattle stock, she wants to obtain a bull. For this purpose, Zina hopes to get a loan. In the future, her plans include her business development, the sale of her apartment and the buying of a house. Where Did This Loan Come From? This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple "P" bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase a cow

loans.name: Laïdou Ii Group

texts.fr:
LAÏDOU II est un regroupement de cinq femmes toutes mariées dans des familles conjugales traditionnelles élargies avec leurs frères, sœurs, co-épouses, enfants et époux. Elles ont   une moyenne d’âge de 28 ans et de 3 enfants et résident à Heremakono-Nord, préfecture de BOUGOUNI, (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).  
Elles se sont connues par des relations de voisinage et de commerce d’articles divers : pâte d’arachide, condiments, préparation et vente de jus de fruits, le tricotage de la laine etc.
Dans l’intention d’acheter plus de produits, afin de satisfaire en quantité et en qualité la clientèle, qui devient de plus nombreuse et exigeante, elles ont décidé d’adhérer à  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso, avec qui  elles sont à leur premier prêt de groupe. 
Avec ce prêt, SAMADJE B., compte acheter des condiments alimentaires de différentes variétés auprès des forains venant de Sikasso et  de Bamako. Elle effectue sa vente, en détail, au comptant et à crédit dans le marché de BOUGOUNI à une clientèle composée essentiellement de femmes. 
Avec ce prêt elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 30.000 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisé dans l’activité et l’autre partie dans les frais d’éducation de leurs enfants.
texts.en: Laidou II is a group of five married women living in traditional extended families with their brothers, sisters, co-wives, children and hubands. They have an average age of 28 years and 3 children and live in Heremakono-Nord in the city of BOUGOUNI (third administrative region of Mali).  They know each other through community and business ties.  They sell various items: peanut paste, condiments, hand-knit wools etc.  They also prepare and sell fruit juices.  Intending to buy more products to meet the quantity and quality expectations of their customer base, which is increasing and becoming more demanding, they decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution. This is their first group loan. SAMADJE BAGAYOO intends to purchase different types of condiments from vendors from Sikasso and Bamako with this loan. She sells her goods at retail, for cash and on credit in the BOUGOUNI market to a clientele composed mainly of women.  She expects to earn a monthly profit of 30,000 CFA with this loan of which a part will be used in the business and the remainder for her children's education expenses.

loans.use: Purchase condiments

loans.name: Gulomjon

texts.en: S. Gulomjon is 54 years old. For many years, together with his children, he has been engaged in the farming business. As his parents were farmers, his only source of income has always been farming and it will always be farming. Gulomjon grows potatoes, onions, carrots, etc. At around 6 a.m., he's already in his fields. He loves his work, but for him to break even and to have a good quality crop, he needs to fumigate and fertilize at very precise dates. During this season, they are sowing in great quantities, and with the help of this loan, Gulomjon will purchase seeds, fertilizer, fuels and lubricants to help with the tilling. He wants to expand his business, a success that will bring a better quality of life for his family. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes being a key post along the Silk Road, and for the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing seeds, fertilizer, fuels and lubricants

loans.name: Badam

texts.en: Badam S. is 57 years old and lives with his wife and son in the Songinohairhan district of Ulaanbaatar, a capital city of Mongolia. He and his family all live together in their ger, a Mongolian nomadic housing tent. His son attends university and works part time while his wife operates a sewing business out of her home. Badam owns his own car and is a taxi driver in the local community. He began his business in 2000 and has gained a lot of business experience over the years. After many years of owning this business, he was able to improve his car several times and his earnings have enabled him to buy a car for his son. By operating his business, he provides for his family and has been improving his family's standard of living. Badam is a hardworking man and says, "All I want is to provide a higher education for my son and help him to live on his own." He is requesting a 1,000,000 Mongolian tugriks loan in order for him to repair his car.

loans.use: To make necessary repairs and replace parts

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Haidar

texts.en: This borrower is from Iraq. He is 38 years old, married and has three children. Haidar has long experience in repairing generators so, in 2001, he decided to open his own maintenance shop. Now he has established a very good reputation and is well known in his community. He is requesting a $2500 loan to renovate his store so he can expand in the future and change his family's quality of life for the better.

loans.use: To renovate his store

loans.name: Yarkul

texts.en:
The business of agriculture and livestock is a job that requires great sacrifice, demanding great efforts which should be carried out in the field, exposed to the sun for many hours and moving animals over long distances. Aware of this situation, Yarkul has been devoted to the agricultural business for more than 5 years. Yarkul has a humble family composed of his wife and 7 children, for whom he provides food and support for their studies. The reason for his requesting a loan is to invest in his agriculture business through seeds and fertilizers.  

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing of seeds and mineral fertilizer.

loans.name: Namhaidorj

texts.en: Namhaidorj T. is 30 years old and lives with his wife and son in Songinohairhan district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. His family lives in a ger (Mongolian nomadic housing tent). His son attends primary school, while his wife works as a teacher in the private school with a monthly salary of 300,000 tugriks (MNT). Namhaidorj operates a taxi service in his community. He began his business in 2007 and has gained a lot of business experience over a short period. After years owing this business, his average daily income is 30,000 MNT and his monthly revenue exceeds 300,000 MNT. Namhaidorj is a modest and kind-hearted man and says, "All I want is to have my own house for my family." He is requesting a 400,000 MNT loan in order to make necessary repairs and purchase four new tires for his car.

loans.use: To make necessary repairs and purchase four new tires

loans.name: Siyatotoba Group

texts.en:
Nkosikhona is 21 years old and single with one child, age 2. She runs a public phone shop in Empangeni, South Africa. She's been in this business for a year, selling airtime on public phones from her shop. She also earns income from a government child support grant. She says that the main challenges to her business are electrical problems that cause her to close her shop. 

She requested this loan from WDB and Kiva to buy airtime for her public phones. She says that the extra income from this loan will help her be able to buy furniture. She would like to grow her business and expand with a beauty store.

Nkosikhona is the leader of her borrower group and is on the far left in the photo above.

loans.use: To purchase airtime for public phones

loans.name: Toama

texts.en: This borrower is from Iraq. He is 58 years old, married and has one child. Toama is well experienced in the upholstery business. He opened his own store in 1975 and he is well known in the area where he lives and works and has an excellent reputation. He is requesting a loan of $3000 to buy a new machine for his business so he can improve his work. He is aiming to expand his business in the future and change his family's quality of life for the better.

loans.use: To buy a new machine for his business

loans.name: Bubuajar's Group

texts.en:
Bubuajar D. is a leader of this group. At her 63, she is unlucky to be a widow. The elder four of her six children are married and live separately, but two of her sons live with her. 
Bubuajar is a pensioner; additionally she gets some money out of cattle breeding and their reselling. Her sons have undertaken everything concerning feeding and pasturing the cattle. Out of profits, they have managed to start house building.
In order to arrange for her sons’ weddings the mother wants to earn more money by increasing cattle stock and so she is planning to purchase cattle. For this plan to be realized successfully, the family hopes to get a loan.  

	--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Annet

texts.en: Annet N. lives in the Kisaasi neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is single and has 6 children, none of whom is in school.  She also takes care of additional family members (grandchildren).    Annet has a business selling charcoal.  She has been in this business for 10 years, and she works 7 days of every week. Annet sells her products as retail from home.     Annet has requested a loan of 400000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO.  She will use it to buy more bags of charcoal.  The main business challenges for Annet include seasonality and transportation.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to start selling at wholesale only and also to build rental rooms.   Annet lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity and doesn't have access to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include food and medication

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Almakan's Group

texts.en:
Almakan A., 37, is the leader of this group. She is married to a builder. The couple has two sons.  The elder son is 34 and works at a mill, and the younger is still a schoolboy. 
In order to make a living, the family is engaged in poultry keeping. This business makes a small profit during the year. Almakan began this type farming just a year ago. 
In order to increase income, the family intends to purchase 20 hens to produce eggs. For this purpose Almakan needs to get a loan. In the future she wants to develop her business by increasing the total number of hens and by selling eggs.

	 --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase hens

loans.name: Ammar

texts.en: This borrower is from Iraq. He is a 26-year-old husband who is living with his family, parents and a sibling. In 2006, Ammar opened a food market to sell a wide variety of products. He is well known in his neighborhood and has a good reputation. He applied for a $2000 loan because he wants to renovate his store. He has always wanted to expand his business to improve his standard of living and his family's lifestyle.

loans.use: To renovate his store

loans.name: Shailon

texts.en:
Shailon A. is 51 years old. She is married with 3 children. As long as she has been married, she has worked in the business of buying and selling sheep. She walks through the farms and several settlements to buy sheep at the lowest price to be able to increase her profits. Now Shailon wants to expand her business. As her children are grown up, Shailon thinks that she will be able to look after more sheep with their help. She asks for $1300 USD in order to purchase sheep. Shailon expresses her gratitude to everyone supporting her and promises to repay the loan in time. 


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing sheep

loans.name: Mairamkul's Group

texts.en:
Mairamkul U. is married. She is 38 years old and has two small sons, both of them of preschool age. Her husband supports the family financially by working as a loader. Mairamkul raises money by selling convenience goods, mainly those for cooking national dishes. During the last four years of regular income, the family has managed to obtain necessary household appliances. 

In order to put their young sons on their feet, this couple wants to increase their family income, so they are planning to increase their goods circulation. Getting a loan may help to realize this plan. In the future Mairamkul wants to develop her business and to obtain a car.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Micro-finance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Micro-finance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. 

To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135
 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase convenience goods for resale

loans.name: Prima

texts.en:
Prima N. lives in the Mengo Mackay neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has two children, both of whom are in school. She lives in a home that she owns where she has access to electricity but does not have access to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include food and medication. 

She has a business of selling charcoal.  She has been in this business for ten years, and she works seven days out of every week, selling her products from home, at retail prices. She generates additional income through rental rooms.

Prima has requested a loan of 400,000 UGX from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags of charcoal. Her main business challenges are seasonality and transportation.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to start selling on a wholesale basis only and also to build more rental rooms.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Kabembe Women's Group A-Mukono

texts.en: 56 Year old B. Rehema has been selling charcoal, chicken, firewood and movie DVD's for the past 21 years in Kabembe-Mukono. She says its her husband who motivated her into starting this business. Her hard working disposition, close friends say has gotten her this far. Most people around her area of operation use charcoal to cook. For that reason, over time she has obtained strong footing on the market for her business. Rehema is happily married with 4 kids. Weekly these businesses generate 250,000 shillings. With this loan, she says she is going to buy more bags of charcoal, firewood, and poultry.

loans.use: The purchase of more bags of charcoal, firewood, and poultry

loans.name: Saijalol

texts.en:
H. Saijalol is a very happy and sociable 56-year-old man. He says he is a happily married man with a hard-working woman who has supported him in achieving all of his dreams. They have ten children and they would have liked to have more. Saijalol’s family is one that loves working in agriculture. The whole family works together to harvest different vegetables. It has been six years since Saijalol began working the land he loves so much. His wife sells the products in the local market. Saijalol also earns some extra income by breeding cattle.

Saijalol is requesting a loan to acquire agricultural supplies that are necessary to maintain the crops. With part of the loan he will also buy young cattle.  His dream is that his children inherit the love to work the land that he and his wife acquired with great effort, and that some day their children will inherit.  

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. loans.use: To buy seeds, mineral fertilizer and young cattle.

loans.name: Bukon's Group

texts.en:
Bukon N. is a widow. She has reared and provided for her only daughter by herself. The daughter is 12 years old and a 6th grade schoolgirl; nevertheless, she helps her mother run the business. The family raises money by selling foodstuffs in their shop nearby. Total earnings make it possible meet their daily requirements. 

In order to improve her family's well-being, Bukon is planning to increase goods circulation and vary the shop assortment (noodles, tea, drinks and cigarettes). For this purpose she hopes to get a loan. 

	--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Micro-finance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Micro-finance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year.

To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase convenience goods for resale

loans.name: Soliya

texts.en:
J. Soliya is a woman who on a daily basis seeks for the bettering of her four children. She works with great effort for them and wants to continue to do so to build a prominent and promising future. Ever since she was a young girl, she has been dedicated to farming activities. She was raised this way and it has been a stable source of income until this day. For more than 15 years Soliya has raised sheep and she also grows some products on her land. 

In order to continue to work and to obtain a very good quantity and quality, Soliya wants to borrow money for growing vegetables and buying sheep. Let’s show solidarity to this self-less widow mother who looks for what is best for her children.
